page.title: 03Highbrook - Ecology
page.content: Much of this part of southern Britain is covered by mixed woodland, with deciduous oak, beech, birch, alder and hazel as well as coniferous plantations. There are all the common wild flowers, a few rare early purple orchids but the area is most famous for its bluebells in the spring. Badgers are not unknown and fallow deer are a nuisance, wandering in from the forest to eat crops and garden produce. All the usual common rodents (mice,rats,grey squirrels) as well as shrews, voles,foxes and rabbits are found in abundance. In the woods jays are common, also nuthatches, sparrows, blue-tits,great-tits,robins, owls, chaffinches and tree-creepers. There are abundant fungi in the autumn.
